pages.title: Week 6 - Computer Vision: Convolutional Neural Networks

elements.content:
[[h3]]Introduction[[/]]
➔ Convolutional Neural Networks are a subset of Artificial Neural Networks that allow us to better work with 2D image data
➔ They have applications in image and video recognition, recommender systems, image classification, medical image analysis, and a lot more
➔ They use convolutions (filters) to work

[[h3]]Why use CNN's?[[/]]
➔ Technically, we can just flatten a 2D image into a 1D array and feed it into a “normal” feedforward Neural Network
➔ However, this will lose a lot of its spatial dependencies (what pixels are next to each other)
➔ Convolutional Neural Networks do a great job capturing spatial and temporal arrangements

pages.title: Week 6 - Convolutional Neural Networks: Inputs and Layers

elements.content:
[[h3]]Attributes of an input image[[/]]
➔ Images have 3 color channels, a width and a height, and every pixels holds 3 values in each color channel
➔ Usually, this color channel is RGB, but sometimes you may see HSV
➔ Convolutional Neural Networks make this into a form that is easier to process without losing important features

[[h3]]Filters[[/]]
➔ Filters are operations applied to images that can be represented as matrices of numbers
➔ This is what Photoshop and other image editing programs use for their filters!
➔ By going over the entire image with the filter, we can transform the way it looks
➔ This filter process is known as a convolution
➔ This forms the basis for a Convolutional Neural Network

[[h3]]Convolution Layer[[/]]
➔ Backbone of a convolutional Neural Network
➔ This contains a set of filters (also called kernels) that move along an image and transform it to extract features such as edges and colors
➔ They have the same depth as the number of color channels in an image
➔ A CNN may have many of these layers to extract more and more high level features

pages.title: Week 6 - Convolutional Neural Networks: More Layers

elements.content:
[[h3]]Pooling Layer[[/]]
➔ The pooling layer functions to reduce the computational power required to process the image data
➔ The pooling layer grabs the most dominant features of an image
➔ Two main types of pooling: max pooling and average pooling
    ◆ Max pooling selects the maximum value in a filter portion
    ◆ Average pooling selects the average value in a filter portion (kernel)

[[h3]]Fully Connected Layer[[/]]
➔ Now, we can flatten the image and feed it into a feedforward Neural Network
➔ This will use backpropagation for a certain number of times until the network learns the dominant features of the image and distinguishes them
➔ This layer works exactly as the Neural Network we learned in the previous chapter

[[h3]]The Goal[[/]]
➔ Draw a bounding box around the recognized object
➔ Identify the recognized object according to determined labels
➔ Predict these with a high accuracy rate
➔ For example - Identify cars in a given image

[[h3]]Bounding Boxes[[/]]
➔ Imaginary rectangle that wraps a target object to be detected
➔ This helps us create a collision box for the object and we can track changes and compare objects to each other
➔ This is one of the most popular image annotation techniques because it reduces costs and increases efficiency

[[h3]]Segmentation[[/]]
➔ Since an image is just a collection of pixels, we can group pixels in the image and label them as objects after using bounding boxes to define the location
➔ Pixels that are grouped together share similar characteristics
➔ This helps in areas like cancer detection, self-driving cars and more that need to separate objects precisely

elements.content:
In this module, you learned all about Computer Vision:
[[h3]]Intro to Convolutional Neural Networks[[/]]
➔ Subset of Artificial Neural Networks that allow us to better work with 2D image data
➔ Applications in image and video recognition, recommender systems, image classification, medical image analysis, and a lot more
➔ Use convolutions (filters) to work
[[h3]]Why use them?[[/]]
➔ Why not just flatten an image and use regular Neural Networks?
➔ Loose a lot of spatial (space-related) and color dependencies - Color boundaries, location of relative objects etc
➔ Convolutional Neural Networks do a great job capturing arrangements
[[h3]]Attributes of images[[/]]
➔ Every pixel with three color channels each - Usually RGB or HSV
➔ Height
➔ Width
[[h3]]Filters[[/]]
➔ Operations applied to images that can be represented as matrices of numbers
➔ Photoshop filters use these
➔ Going over the entire images changes how it looks
➔ Filter process is known as convolution
[[h3]]Convolutional Layer[[/]]
➔ The backbone of a Convolutional Neural Networks
➔ Contains a set of filters (also called kernels) that move along an image and transform it to extract features such as edges and colors
➔ Same depth as the number of color channels in an image
➔ A CNN may have many of these layers to extract more and more high-level features
[[h3]]Pooling Layer[[/]]
➔ Used to reduce the computational power required to process the image data
➔ Grabs the most dominant features of an image
➔ Two types - Max Pooling(select max in filter portion) and Average Pooling(get average in filter portion)
[[h3]]Fully Connected Layer[[/]]
➔ Final Part
➔ Flatten the image and feed into Neural Network with data from convolutions and pooling
➔ Uses backpropagation to learn dominant features and distinguish them
➔ Works exactly as the Neural Network we learned in the previous chapter
[[h3]]NeuroEvolution[[/]]
➔ Object Detection/Localization
➔ Draw bounding box within an image around a recognized image
➔ Identify the recognized object
➔ Predict with a high accuracy
➔ Bounding Box - A popular technique to make an area of identification for an object within an image; can track changes in a video
➔ Segmentation - identify exact parts of an image by drawing boundaries around object and other parts of the image
